questionsReworded.originalQuestion: Using the same data: Beginning inventory: 100 units @ $10; Purchase 1: 150 units @ $12; Purchase 2: 200 units @ $14. If 300 units were sold, what is ending inventory under LIFO?
questionsReworded.newQuestion: A company has: Beginning inventory: 100 units @ $10; Purchase 1: 150 units @ $12; Purchase 2: 200 units @ $14. If 300 units were sold, what is ending inventory under LIFO?

questionsReworded.originalQuestion: Using the previous example (lease liability $42,124, 6% rate, $10,000 annual payment), what is Year 1 interest expense?
questionsReworded.newQuestion: A finance lease has an initial lease liability of $42,124, a 6% interest rate, and $10,000 annual payments. What is Year 1 interest expense?

questionsReworded.originalQuestion: Using the previous question's facts ($300 upfront + $50/month Ã— 12 months), what is the monthly revenue recognition?
questionsReworded.newQuestion: A gym membership requires a $300 non-refundable upfront fee plus $50/month for 12 months. The upfront fee does not provide any distinct benefit. What is the monthly revenue recognition?

questionsReworded.originalQuestion: Using the previous data (66.7% ratio), if ending inventory at retail is $75,000, what is ending inventory at cost?
questionsReworded.newQuestion: A retailer uses the retail inventory method with a cost-to-retail ratio of 66.7%. If ending inventory at retail is $75,000, what is ending inventory at cost?

questionsReworded.originalQuestion: Using the previous example (30% ownership, $500,000 income, $100,000 dividends), what is the effect of dividends on the investment account?
questionsReworded.newQuestion: An investor owns 30% of an investee that reports $500,000 net income and declares $100,000 in total dividends. Under the equity method, what is the effect of the dividends on the investment account?

questionsReworded.originalQuestion: Using the previous data (AR turnover = 12), what are days sales outstanding?
questionsReworded.newQuestion: A company has an accounts receivable turnover ratio of 12 times per year. What are the days sales outstanding (DSO)?

questionsReworded.originalQuestion: Using the same facts (basis $100K, FMV given $250K, received property $220K + $30K cash), the basis of the replacement property is:
questionsReworded.newQuestion: In a like-kind exchange, a taxpayer exchanges property with a basis of $100,000 and FMV of $250,000 for property worth $220,000 plus $30,000 cash. What is the basis of the replacement property?

questionsReworded.originalQuestion: Using the same facts (basis $40,000, FMV $100,000, sale price $60,000), what gain must the taxpayer recognize on the bargain sale?
questionsReworded.newQuestion: A taxpayer makes a bargain sale to a charity, selling property with a basis of $40,000 and FMV of $100,000 for $60,000. What gain must the taxpayer recognize?
